passage_list.text: Jen keeps a steamer trunk of Bobby’s things in the attic above her garage. In anticipation of my arrival, she’s brought his belongings down in a turquoise canvas bag. She starts sifting through it. “There’s the diary,” she says, pointing. “The thing that caused all that trouble.”

Bobby’s other two diaries were hundreds of pages long. This one, I will shortly discover, had only seventeen pages of entries. All that fuss over what was barely a pamphlet. Then again, they’re a dense seventeen pages.

Jen has no memory of getting the diary from Bob Sr. But she does remember reading it immediately, voraciously, and returning to it night after night. She remembers, too, Helen asking for it back, though the tensions didn’t start immediately. At first, everything was fine. Helen even gave her the engagement ring Bobby had bought for her. It was awkward and unceremonious—”He’d have wanted you to have this”—but Jen was grateful, and she wore it everywhere for months.

At some point, though, Helen started getting more vocal about that diary. “In hindsight, I don’t know what my problem was,” Jen says. “I was probably in pain and also grasping for control and wanted something of his that no one else had. It seems kind of ridiculous now. It’s just how I felt at the time—that it was mine and I wanted it to be mine and I didn’t want anyone else to have it. It probably felt like it was all I had left.”

What I had to understand about those awful, leaden days, Jen says, is that she wasn’t just depressed. She was wretched—“double grieving,” as she puts it, for her mother and then her future husband. When her mother and Bobby died in rapid succession, she fell into a deep depression, though she did her valiant best to conceal it. She still has anxiety attacks to this day. “When something upsets me,” she says, “it goes downhill fast.”

Which all makes perfect sense, I say. The only thing I can’t understand is why she refused to transcribe the nonpersonal parts of Bobby’s diary for Helen. That’s not the act of a depressed person or a grieving person. That’s the act of someone who’s angry. She must have been upset with Helen for some reason, no?

Here Jen pauses. Then she starts measuring her words. “This isn’t a knock on Helen at all,” she says. “I’m so beyond it. But at the time I remember resenting that she said, ‘You’re going to be okay, because you’re young.’ ” Jen recognized that there was a difference between their two losses. “But it felt like she was saying my grief was less important than hers. I know it was coming from a place of extreme pain, but I remember thinking, How does she know I’m going to be okay? What if I’m not okay? What if I have a different kind of not-okay?”

One thing you don’t say to a person who’s mourning, Jen tells me, is that they’re going to be okay. She might have added: nor do you say that to a depressed person. Depression does that—convinces you that you are never going to be okay.

“Now I get it,” she says. Because of course Helen was right. Jen did find love again. But at the time, she was convinced that she wouldn’t. She considered freezing her eggs. Once, in a moment of near-hallucinatory panic, she wondered if she could get impregnated with Bobby’s DNA from strands of hair he’d left in a comb.

“It just would’ve come out better if she’d said: ‘This is really sucky for you. And I’m sorry. Chances are, you’ll meet somebody.’ I guess there was just a nicer way to say it,” she says. “However she said it set me off. Just because of my own personal shit.”

questions.question: What is the main focus of the passage?

options.C: The trouble caused by Bobby’s diary
options.D: Jen’s anticipation of the author’s arrival

questions.explanation: The passage focuses on Jen’s collection of Bobby’s belongings, particularly the diary, which she brings down in anticipation of the author’s arrival.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the central subject of the passage and avoid being distracted by secondary details.

questions.question: As used in the passage, what does the word 'dense' most nearly mean?
questions.explanation: In this context, 'dense' refers to the complexity and depth of the content within the diary’s seventeen pages.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use context clues to infer the meaning of words that describe the nature of written content.

questions.question: What can be inferred about Jen’s relationship with Helen?

options.A: They were always in conflict over Bobby’s diary.
options.B: Their relationship was initially cordial but later became strained.
options.C: Helen was jealous of Jen’s possession of Bobby’s diary.
options.D: Jen resented Helen for giving her Bobby’s engagement ring.

questions.explanation: The passage indicates that tensions between Jen and Helen over the diary did not start immediately, suggesting their relationship was initially cordial but later became strained.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for implicit information that is not directly stated but can be logically inferred from the text.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Jen’s reflection on her past actions?

options.A: To express regret over her behavior
options.B: To explain her emotional state at the time
options.C: To criticize Helen’s handling of the situation
options.D: To justify her decision to keep the diary

questions.explanation: Jen’s reflection serves to explain her emotional state and the reasons behind her actions during a period of intense grief and pain.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay attention to the author's or character's intent when analyzing statements or quotes in the text.

questions.question: Which choice best describes Jen’s emotional state during the “awful, leaden days”?

options.A: She was overwhelmed by grief and depression.
options.B: She was angry at Helen for her lack of support.
options.C: She was indifferent to the events around her.
options.D: She was hopeful about finding love again.

questions.explanation: Jen describes herself as “double grieving” and falling into a deep depression, indicating she was overwhelmed by grief and depression.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Analyze the character's emotional response and the reasons behind it to understand their perspective.

questions.question: Which piece of evidence best supports the idea that Jen’s refusal to transcribe the diary was an act of anger?

options.A: Jen’s description of her emotional state as “double grieving.”
options.B: The author’s observation that Jen’s refusal was not typical of a grieving person.
options.C: Jen’s admission that she was grasping for control.
options.D: Helen’s request for the nonpersonal parts of the diary.

questions.explanation: The author explicitly states that Jen’s refusal to transcribe the diary was not the act of a depressed or grieving person but rather someone who was angry.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify direct textual evidence that supports the main idea or specific claims in the passage.

questions.question: How does Jen’s reflection on Helen’s comment, “You’re going to be okay, because you’re young,” relate to her emotional state at the time?

options.A: It highlights Jen’s belief that her grief was less significant.
options.B: It shows Jen’s resentment toward Helen for minimizing her pain.
options.C: It demonstrates Jen’s acceptance of Helen’s perspective.
options.D: It reveals Jen’s gratitude for Helen’s support.

questions.explanation: Jen’s reflection indicates that she resented Helen’s comment because it felt like her grief was being minimized, which exacerbated her emotional pain.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Analyze how different parts of the text connect to support or explain a character's actions or decisions.

questions.question: What can be inferred about the impact of depression on Jen’s perception of her future?

options.A: It made her optimistic about finding love again.
options.B: It convinced her that she would never recover.
options.C: It led her to seek professional help immediately.
options.D: It caused her to distance herself from Helen.

questions.explanation: Jen’s statement that depression convinces you that you are never going to be okay suggests that it made her pessimistic about her future.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use descriptive language and emotional cues in the text to infer a character's feelings or state of mind.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Jen’s statement, “Now I get it”?

options.A: To express her current understanding of Helen’s perspective.
options.C: To criticize Helen’s lack of empathy.

questions.explanation: Jen’s statement reflects her current understanding and acceptance of Helen’s perspective, which she initially resented.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Consider the broader context and implications of specific events or situations described in the text.

questions.question: Which choice best maintains the grammatical and logical coherence of the following sentence? “It just would’ve come out better if she’d said: ‘This is really sucky for you. And I’m sorry. Chances are, you’ll meet somebody.’”

options.B: It just would’ve come out better if she’d said, “This is really sucky for you, and I’m sorry, chances are, you’ll meet somebody.”
options.C: It just would’ve come out better if she’d said: “This is really sucky for you, and I’m sorry. Chances are, you’ll meet somebody.”
options.D: It just would’ve come out better if she’d said: “This is really sucky for you. And I’m sorry, chances are, you’ll meet somebody.”

questions.explanation: The sentence maintains proper grammatical structure and logical flow, with clear punctuation and capitalization.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Ensure that sentences maintain proper grammatical structure and logical flow, especially when dealing with complex ideas.

scoring_guidelines.800_level_performance: Students scoring at this level demonstrate mastery of all tested skills, including advanced analysis, synthesis, and reasoning.
scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students scoring at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may struggle with higher-level analysis and synthesis.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, often requiring students to infer meaning or analyze complex text structures.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess comprehension and vocabulary in context, with a focus on understanding main ideas and details.
explanation_summary.easy_questions: Easy questions evaluate basic comprehension and the ability to identify explicit information in the text.
